title: How to Care for Your Silverware

steps.headline: Wash silverware promptly after every meal to keep them free from tarnish and discoloration.
Wipe them dry.
steps.description: Do not leave them to dry themselves.

steps.headline: Do not soak silverware in water for hours.
steps.description: Doing so loosens the knife handles and dulls the finish.

steps.headline: If your silverware set has many pieces, make sure each piece gets equal use.
Do not spray hollow ware with lacquer or plastic.
Wash silverware immediately after contact with food like eggs, mayonnaise, mustard and any form of rubber, because they tarnish the silver.
Apply silver cleaner on a soft, clean cloth.
Use gentle, lengthwise stroke until tarnish is removed.
steps.description: Follow the contour of each piece. Never use circular or rubbing motion.

steps.headline: Wash silverware in hot, sudsy water and rinse in hot, clean water.
Dry each piece right after washing using a fresh clean cloth.
Keep silverware from constant exposure to air to prevent tarnish.

text: Care for Silverware Wash silverware promptly after every meal to keep them free from tarnish and discoloration.  Wipe them dry. Do not leave them to dry themselves. Do not soak silverware in water for hours. Doing so loosens the knife handles and dulls the finish. If your silverware set has many pieces, make sure each piece gets equal use.  Do not spray hollow ware with lacquer or plastic.  Wash silverware immediately after contact with food like eggs, mayonnaise, mustard and any form of rubber, because they tarnish the silver.  Keep silverware dry.  Cleaning Silverware Apply silver cleaner on a soft, clean cloth.  Use gentle, lengthwise stroke until tarnish is removed. Follow the contour of each piece. Never use circular or rubbing motion. Wash silverware in hot, sudsy water and rinse in hot, clean water.  Dry each piece right after washing using a fresh clean cloth.  Proper Storage Keep silverware from getting scratched.  Keep silverware from constant exposure to air to prevent tarnish.  Wrap silverware in flannel wrappings.
